sections.title: Syntax
sections.raw_content:
A closeStatement is:

  close : fileNumber

sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: In Turing, files are read and written using a fileNumber. In most cases, this number is given a value using the open statement, which translates a file name, such as "Master", to a file number, such as 5. When the program is finished using the file, it disconnects from the file using the close statement.

In most cases, this number is given a value using the **open** statement, which translates a file name, such as "Master", to a file number, such as 5. When the program is finished using the file, it disconnects from the file using the **close** statement.

sections.title: Example
code:
var fileName : string := "Master"   % Name of file
        var fileNo : int                % Number of file
        var inputVariable : string (100)
        open : fileNo, fileName, read
        
        read : fileNo, inputVariable
        
        close : fileNo
sections.raw_content: This program illustrates how to open, read and then close a file.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content:
In a Turing implementation, there will generally be a limit on the number of currently open files. This limit will typically be around 20. To avoid exceeding this limit, a program that uses many files one after another should close files that are no longer in use.

If a program does not close a file, the file will be automatically closed when the program finishes.
